item.title: Popular Zero-Day Options Strategies Keep a Lid on Stock Rallies
item.description: Investors’ daily waves of option sales are poised to slow a sustained stock rally back to record highs.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

media:content.media:description: UBS Derivatives Strategy

item.title: Greece to Supply Ukraine With US Natural Gas From December
item.description: Ukraine said it’s reached an agreement with Greece that will help secure the supply of natural gas for the coming winter heating season.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

media:content.media:description: Greece's prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis greets the President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Maximos Mansion in Athens, Greece during an unofficial visit in Greece, on Nov. 16, 2025 (Photo by Dimitris Kapantais / SOOC via AFP) (Photo by DIMITRIS KAPANTAIS/SOOC/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Can the World Afford to Retire? How One Country is Addressing the Crisis
item.description: Around the world, market forces – low interest rates, longer lives, workers changing jobs – are testing underfunded pension plans. We explore how the world should rethink financial security for aging populations. The Netherlands offers one solution by taking on more risk for younger populations. Economist Teresa Ghilarducci explains why countries like the US have kicked the can down the road, while Dutch experts Adrian Rikjen and Stan Veuger highlight how a pivot toward defined contributions could make the system sustainable. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Crowded Emerging-Market Trades Draw Warnings From Money Managers
item.description: Some of the year’s most popular emerging-market trades such as betting on the Brazilian real and stocks linked to artificial intelligence are becoming a source of concern as money managers warn of risks from overcrowding.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong, Carolina Wilson, Srinivasan Sivabalan

media:content.media:description: US dollar and Brazilian real exchange rates displayed at a store in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, Oct. 6, 2025. Economy Minister Luis Caputo continues his visit to DC to finalize the design of the financial support that the US will provide to the country.

item.title: South Africa Moves Ahead With Nuclear Power Expansion Plans
item.description: South Africa will move forward with plans to build a new nuclear plant and revive its modular nuclear reactor program, part of a broader push to secure long-term energy stability, Electricity Minister Kgosientsho Ramakgopa said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: The Koeberg nuclear power station, operated by Eskom Holdings SOC Ltd., viewed from Melkbosstrand beach in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, Nov. 25, 2020. The decision to begin installing new steam generators at the Koeberg plant near Cape Town underscores state-owned Eskom’s confidence that it will win approval to prolong production of low-emissions nuclear power into the middle of the century.

item.title: Europe Gauges Fallout From Trump’s Year of Trade Chaos
item.description: European Union officials may cut growth forecasts for 2026 in the coming week in an assessment of damage to the region’s economy, a year after Donald Trump won back the White House.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Bound aluminum plates ahead of shipping at the Aluminum Dunkerque SAS aluminium smelter near Dunkirk, France, on Monday, March 17, 2025. After weeks of uncertainty that ricocheted through markets, President Trump’s 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from every country in the world went into effect on Wednesday morning.

item.title: India’s Hygenco May Sell 49% Stake for $125 Million, Mint Says
item.description: Hygenco Green Energies Pvt may sell a 49% stake to a consortium including the World Bank’s International Finance Corp. for $125 million, helping the Indian company to realize its goal to develop 10 gigawatts of green hydrogen production capacity by the end of the decade, Mint newspaper reported, citing unidentified people.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Vapour rises near a chimney at the Galp Energia SGPS SA Sines refinery plant in Sines, Portugal, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. Galp expects its biofuels and green hydrogen projects located at the Sines refinery will be operating in mid-2026. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Thailand Says US Trade Talks Separated From Cambodia Border Deal
item.description: Thailand said tariff talks with the US will move forward on a separate track from its commitments to President Donald Trump related to its border dispute with Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: Vehicles travel past shipping containers and gantry cranes at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, Sept. 2, 2020. Thailand has reported zero locally-transmitted Covid-19 cases for 100 days in a row, joining a small group of places like Taiwan where the pathogen has been virtually eliminated. Photograph: Taylor Weidman/Bloomberg

item.title: Pop Mart’s Labubu Risks Beanie Baby-Style Collapse, Analyst Says
item.description: The euphoria surrounding Labubu toys is starting to resemble the boom-and-bust cycle that ended in the collapse of Beanie Babies in the 1990s, a warning sign for investors, a bearish analyst says.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Labubu dolls on display at Pop Mart’s “Monsters by Monsters: Now and Then” 10-year anniversary exhibition in Shanghai last month.

item.title: Rich Talent Group CEO Nicole Reboe on Key Diversity Trends in Executive Hiring
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is promoting the smallest proportion of women to managing director since Chief Executive Officer David Solomon took the top job in 2018. Women comprise 27% of Goldman’s new managing director class, according to numbers released by the firm earlier this month. That compares with 31% in the last set of managing director promotions in 2023. Nicole Reboe, the CEO of Rich Talent Group, discusses whether she sees trends like this playing out across the broader business landscape, and why it remains critical for corporate leaders to continue pursuing a diverse mix of talent. Nicole speaks with Carol Massar, Tim Stenovec and Bloomberg News Managing Diversity Reporter Jeff Green on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB’s Rehn Says Must Account for Risk of Slowing Inflation
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council Member Olli Rehn said the risk of inflation slowing shouldn’t be overlooked, Helsingin Sanomat reported.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: Olli Rehn Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: AI Debt Explosion Has Traders Searching for Cover: Credit Weekly
item.description: As tech companies gear up to borrow hundreds of billions of dollars to fuel investments in artificial intelligence, lenders and investors are increasingly looking to protect themselves against it all going wrong.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Mutua

media:content.media:description: Attendees wait in line to enter the Moscone Center North building during the Oracle OpenWorld 2017 conference in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2017. Oracle Corp. plans to pay its leaders more than $100 million each in fiscal 2018, an increase of about 150 percent, as it rips a page from Tesla Inc.'s playbook to change its executive-compensation practices in response to investor complaints.

item.title: JBS Venture Agrees to Buy Hickman’s in Push for US Egg Market
item.description: Mantiqueira USA Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the joint venture between JBS and the founders of Mantiqueira Alimentos, entered into a binding agreement to acquire Hickman’s Egg Ranch, expanding the participation of the world’s largest meat producer in the egg sector.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Almeida

media:content.media:description: Eggs collected from ISA Brown chickens at an egg farm in Mason, Michigan, US, on Monday, March 3, 2025. Egg prices have soared to a record of over $8 a dozen, driven by the worst-ever outbreak of avian flu in the US and contributing to broader inflation pressures. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

item.title: Argentina Power Firm Genneia Eyes First US IPO of Milei Era
item.description: Argentine power producer Genneia SA is preparing an initial public offering in New York for as soon as the first quarter of 2026, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert, Ignacio Olivera Doll, Nicolle Yapur

media:content.media:description: A power substation in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Argentina Awaits Data Before Seeking to Renegotiate IMF Targets
item.description: Argentine officials are waiting until the end of the year to determine whether to renegotiate any terms of a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund, including targets on foreign reserves, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Argentina in the financial district of Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Tuesday, Sept. 23, 2025. One of the biggest problems Argentine President Javier Milei has as he tries to stem a currency crisis is that the peso, by nearly all accounts, is overvalued.

item.title: WPP Draws Interest from Havas and Private Equity, Times Says
item.description: The advertising agency Havas N.V. has expressed interest in WPP Plc, the Times reported, without saying how it got the information.
item.dc:creator: Valentine Baldassari

media:content.media:description: A company plaque is seen outside the offices of British advertising giant WPP in London on August 23, 2017. - The British advertising giant WPP has downgraded its growth forecast for 2017 because of a slowdown in the market, causing a fall of over 10 per cent in the company's stock price. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP) (Photo by DANIEL LEAL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: US Coffee Tariffs Remain Too High, Says Top Supplier Brazil
item.description: Brazil will keep pushing to get further tariff relief from the US on coffee exports after US President Donald Trump’s decision to lower levies barely impacted its largest supplier.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Almeida, Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Workers dump harvested coffee cherries into a truck on a farm in Guaxupe, Minas Gerais state, Brazil, on Wednesday, June 2, 2021. The severe drought in agricultural powerhouse Brazil is shaking up the world's crop markets again, this time because farmers in the top exporting country are finding they can't meet sales agreements made months ago.

item.title: Google to Lift India Data Hub Plan Above $15 Billion
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Google is expected to boost its investment in Andhra Pradesh beyond $15 billion after five years, according to the leader of the southern Indian state. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Beyond AI: Inside the Global Quantum Computer Race
item.description: Einstein doubted it. But nearly a century later, quantum mechanics is driving one of the biggest technology races of our time. From drug discovery to finance and cybersecurity, the quantum revolution may redefine how we compute, invest, and live, and it could even outperform AI. IBM’s Jamie Garcia and Jerry Chow explain why 2029 is the year to watch for quantum, while IonQ’s Niccolo de Masi says his company is already years ahead. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Refusal Pushes Serbia to Weigh Seizing NIS, Minister Says
item.description: The steadfast US stance on sanctions against Serbia’s sole refiner, NIS AD, has left Belgrade facing a stark choice: seize the company from Russia, or risk running out of crude, said Energy Minister Dubravka Djedovic-Handanovic.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: Workers walk towards refining towers and pipework at the Naftna Industrija Srbija AD (NIS) deep oil processing and refining complex, operated by Gazprom PJSC, in Pancevo, Serbia, on Wednesday, Nov. 18, 2020. Russia’s biggest energy firms plan to expand production in the coming decades and, unlike their peers in Europe, haven’t pledged to transition to renewables.

item.title: Wall Street Week | Santander’s Ana Botín, Quantum Future, Pension Reform, Data Center Win-Win
item.description: This week, Santander’s Ana Botín is steering one of Europe’s biggest banks through red tape and rising taxes. She says that growth, not regulation, is what Europe needs most. And, quantum mechanics is driving a multibillion-dollar race. The technology is already in use, but measuring success is the next challenge for investors. Plus, the Netherlands is offering a blueprint for how pension systems around the world adapt. Later, can Finland’s plan to turn data center heat into clean power work worldwide? (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Banco Santander and ionQ Show Innovation Needs Both Money and Math
item.description: Investors are putting billions of dollars into bringing quantum computing into the real world.
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: A wax figure of Albert Einstein, German-born physicist, stands on display at Madame Tussauds prior to the exhibition's public opening, in Berlin, Germany, on Thursday, July 3, 2008. Organizers decided not to show Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler upright in uniform, ready for world domination, as he is in the London branch -- where he also features frequently in tourists' snapshots. His is instead slumped at his desk, lost in thought, a broken man confined to his bunker. Photographer: Adam Berry/Bloomberg News

item.title: Consumers Feel Pinch at Pump as Russia Drives Oil Refining Boom
item.description: It’s a great time to be an oil refiner — but a less great time to be filling up at the pump.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Veena Ali-Khan, Nicholas Lua, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: HOUSTON, TEXAS - AUGUST 28: In an aerial view, the Valero Houston refinery is seen on August 28, 2023 in Houston, Texas. (Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)

item.title: Benin MPs Vote to Extend Presidential Terms Ahead of 2026 Vote
item.description: Benin’s lawmakers voted to extend the term of office of the country’s presidents to seven from five years, renewable once, less than six months before next year’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: A general view of a political banner depicting Benin Finance Minister and ruling coalition's presidential candidate Romuald Wadagni (L) and his running mate, Benin Deputy President Mariam Chabi Talata (R), during their investiture ceremony Parakou's Municipal Stadium in Parakou, on October 4, 2025. (Photo by Yanick FOLLY / AFP) (Photo by YANICK FOLLY/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Reeves Faces Industry Pushback Over Minimum ISA Allocation to UK
item.description: Rachel Reeves is facing pushback from some major investment platforms on a proposal to revamp individual savings accounts, a setback for the UK Chancellor less than two weeks ahead of her budget.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper, James Woolcock

media:content.media:description: WADDINGTON, LINCOLNSHIRE - FEBRUARY 28: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves hosts a roundtable with the defence sector as she visits RAF Waddington on February 28, 2025 in Waddington, United Kingdom. Chancellor Rachel Reeves, Business and Trade Secretary Jonathan Reynolds, Defence Secretary John Healey are hosting a roundtable event with the defence sector. (Photo by Yui Mok-WPA Pool/Getty Images)

item.title: Swiss Tariff Deal Brings Relief to Struggling Watchmakers
item.description: Companies have cut workers’ hours as US exports plunged
item.dc:creator: Allegra Catelli, Jinshan Hong

media:content.media:description: La Chaux-de-Fonds is considered one of the hubs of Swiss watchmaking.

item.title: Citi's Dirk Willer on How You Know When the Bubble Is Over
item.description: Just accept that you can't time it perfectly.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, Oct. 12, 2018. U.S. stocks surged Friday after two days of market tumult as trade tensions with China seemed to ease, at least temporarily, with the countries planning to meet in November and the Treasury Department saying that China isn't manipulating its currency.

item.title: Odd Lots: Dirk Willer on How To Know a Bubble Is Over (Podcast)
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Turkish Reality-TV King Ilicali Eyes IPO for His Broadcaster TV8
item.description: Turkish media mogul Acun Ilicali, who built an entertainment franchise around taking global reality shows and adapting them for a local audience, is preparing to test investor appetite for his prime-time empire.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: Acun Ilicali watches Hull City football club in Hull, UK.

item.title: Paradise Island in Mozambique Is Getting a $102 Million Upgrade
item.description: Mozambique’s Santa Carolina island, made famous in the global reality show Survivor, is set for a $102-million upgrade by a South African luxury safari travel company.
item.dc:creator: Tavares Cebola

media:content.media:description: An aerial view over Santa Carolina, Mozambique.
